ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HDB SHOPS
(Deferment of rental increases)


    1. Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the current recession, whether he will consider asking the Housing and Development Board to defer implementing the third stage of rental increases for HDB shophouses due in September 1986

Column: 658

in order to alleviate the business and financial difficulties of these shopkeepers.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the third stage rental increase for shophouses affected by the 1983 rental revision exercise has been deferred for one year till September 1986. It is still too early to consider further deferment of the rental increase. However, the request by the Member will be favourably considered when the matter comes under review in the middle of this year.

Column: 659

FREE WEEKEND PARKING IN AYER RAJAH
(Extension to other housing estates)


    2. Encik Ibrahim Othman asked the Minister for National Development (a) how successful is the pilot free parking scheme introduced in the Ayer Rajah Constituency; and (b) whether such a scheme will be extended to other housing estates, when popularly requested.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the pilot scheme to have free parking on Sundays and public holidays is being tried out at the car parks in Ayer Rajah Constituency for a period of six months. Since its introduction on 1st December 1985, indiscriminate parking of vehicles was observed at some of the car parks in the Constituency. However, as the pilot project has only been in operation for the last three months, it is too early to draw any conclusion on the feasibility of the scheme.

    The HDB will continue to monitor the situation closely before deciding at the end of the six months' trial period on whether to extend the free parking scheme to other housing estates.

     Encik Ibrahim Othman (Tanah Merah): Sir, can the Minister explain whether the indiscriminate parking is due to the lack of space or due to too many vehicles?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, sometimes it is due to both. In certain popular car parks, more cars are parked, causing indiscriminate parking and a little bit of confusion.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister, by way of a supplementary question, whether the Ministry would consider a downward revision of the parking fees paid in housing estates? If his answer is that he will not consider, would he tell us why not?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry will not consider a downward revision of parking fees. I think the $25 a month parking charge is very low in the present situation.

Column: 660

VACANT LAND AT ALEXANDRA TERRACE AND FORMER PERAK HOUSE
(Development plans)


    The following Question stood in the name of Encik Abbas Abu Amin -

    3. To ask the Minister for National Development what are the plans for developing the vacant land at (i) Alexandra Terrace and Alexandra Lane, and (ii) the former Perak House, next to the Pasir Panjang Community Centre.

     Mr Speaker: Encik Abbas.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe (Geylang Serai): Question No. 3, Sir.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the land at Alexandra Terrace and Alexandra Lane was acquired for development by the Port of Singapore Authority.

    The former Perak House next to the Pasir Panjang Community Centre has been relocated to the former Radin Mas School. The vacated building has since been demolished and the land is in State ownership. There are no plans for development at present.

Column: 660

STUDY OF TAMIL AS SECOND LANGUAGE IN SCHOOLS


    4. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the Minister for Education (a) how many students are offering TL2 in our schools; (b) how many students take TL2 lessons as part of their curriculum in the schools; (c) how many students go to Tamil Language Centres for the TL2 lessons; and (d) what plans the Ministry has to make teaching of TL2 part of the school curriculum.

     The Minister for Education (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, 16,058 students are offering TL2 in our schools and junior colleges. Of these, 13,253 students take TL2 lessons as part of their curriculum in the schools and 2,805 students go to Tamil language centres for the TL2 lessons.

    Sir, the Ministry will continue to increase the number of schools teaching TL2 within the school curriculum, subject to constraints of manpower and efficient utilization of resources.

Column: 661

DEMAND FOR HDB FLATS
(Effects of retrenchment and reduced CPF contributions)


    5. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for National Development whether the reduction of 15% of employers' contribution to the Central Provident Fund and the retrenchment problem will lead to a reduction in the demand for Housing and Development Board flats thereby depressing further the construction industry.

Column: 661



    6. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for National Development whether tenants of Housing and Development Board flats who intend to purchase flats will be affected by the reduction in the Central Provident Fund contribution and the unemployment situation thereby affecting the Government's plan to achieve a 100% home ownership by 1990.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, since Questions 5 and 6 by the Member for Telok Blangah are related, I will answer them together.

    The HDB has already implemented various measures to help existing tenants and prospective home buyers to purchase flats. Tenants buying 3-room and 4-room simplified flats need only pay a 5% downpayment. They can also take up mortgage loans of up to 95% of the selling price and repay the loans over 25 years. Under the Ballooning Repayment Scheme, home buyers need only pay 75% of what the normal monthly repayments would have been in the early years of the loan. As the 15% reduction in employer's contribution translates into a 25% total reduction in CPF available for housing payments, the ballooning scheme will enable new buyers to pay for their flats as if the CPF deduction had not taken place. Thus, the 15% reduction in the employer's contribution to the CPF is likely to have little impact on the demand for public housing.

    Sir, we are unable to tell to what extent the demand for public housing will be affected by retrenchment. However, there has been no significant drop in the number of new applications for purchase of HDB flats so far. In the first two months of this year, a total of 7,800 new applicants have registered with the HDB. If this trend con-

Column: 662

tinues, the number of new applications for 1986 will be around 45,000.

    Our public housing building programme is geared to meet demand. As of today, there are still more than 52,000 applicants waiting to buy HDB flats. The HDB's building programme is already committed in the next two years to meet this demand. There will therefore be no depressing effects on the construction industry in the next two years. Government's objective of achieving 100% home ownership by 1999 is unlikely to be affected.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Mr Speaker, Sir, could the 5% downpayment be further reduced or waived in view of the present economic recession?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the 5% downpayment is a very small sum.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Only to you!

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Any home buyer who wishes to own a home should make some effort.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, my supplementary question relates to Question 5. Is there a good response to the new scheme which was implemented in December 1985 for tenants of HDB rental flats to purchase flats?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes, there is a good response. I think there are more than 2,000 tenants who have applied under this special scheme to own their flats.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, will the Minister tell us how many persons who purchased flats have now applied to return their flats to the HDB because they are unable to continue with their instalment payments?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I think the number is very small. Offhand, I do not have the exact number with me. If the Member for Anson submits a written question, the answer will be given to him.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Tomorrow.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, out of the 7,200 applicants, how many of them are first-time applicants, ie, those who are not upgrading themselves to a better flat?

Column: 663



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, again, I cannot give the figure offhand. Approximately, I would say 25% of the applicants are upgrading to bigger flats. Another 25% of the applicants are already residents in HDB estates but they are "split families", in other words, the children got married and have applied for new homes as they are moving out of their present homes. There may be another 10% who form their own family nucleus perhaps with their spouse who is not an HDB resident.

     Dr Aline K. Wong (Changkat): Sir, could the Minister please clarify these figures for me? Does the projected number of new applicants of 45,000 for 1986 plus the figure of 52,000 applicants on the present waiting list constitute the total waiting list? The HDB has announced that to cater to this wasiting list, it intends to build 160,000 new units by the end of the decade. How did the HDB come to this figure? Has this total waiting list been taken into consideration in HDB's building programme of 160,000 units?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, just now I said that there were 7,800 applications in the last two months. The projection is based on this trend. If this present rate of slightly under 4,000 a month continues, then we will reach the figure of 45,000. But we may or may not reach this figure.

     Dr Ang Kok Peng (Buona Vista): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether the 2,000 applicants from the rental flats have indicated that the prices of the flats that they intend to buy are beyond their means?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the answer is no. If the price is beyond their means, they will not apply.

     Dr Aline Wong: Sir, I do not think the Minister has answered the second part of my question. It has been announced that HDB will build 160,000 units by the end of the decade. My question was: based on the projection of the required housing need of 45,000 plus the existing waiting list of 52,000, has this total number of units been taken into consideration in the building programme of HDB of 160,000 units?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the proposed HDB's programme between 1986 and 1990

Column: 664

is 160,000. This is the proposed programme. The HDB's policy has always been to build in order to meet demand. The demand, judging from the waiting list, has always been reviewed every six months. If the demand is greater, such as between 1981 and 1985, the HDB in fact had to build more than the programme. If the demand comes down, then HDB will reduce the programme accordingly.

Column: 664

AYER RAJAH EXPRESSWAY AND OVERHEAD BRIDGES


    7. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for National Development when the Ayer Rajah Expressway will be completed and what steps are being taken to build overhead bridges, especially at the junction of North Buona Vista Road and Lower Kent Ridge Road, near the National University of Singapore.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ayer Rajah Expressway will be fully completed by 1988. The Keppel Viaduct, which is the starting point of the Expressway, was opened to traffic in September last year. The next section between the Viaduct and the Alexandra Road will be open to traffic next month. The final section is formed by Ayer Rajah Road and Upper Ayear Rajah Road. Construction work will commence sometime this year.

    When fully completed, there will be a total of 12 pedestrian overhead bridges and one underpass along the Expressway. Two of these pedestrian overhead bridges will be constructed at the junction of North Buona Vista Road and Lower Kent Ridge Road.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask a supplementary question? I see that part of the Ayer Rajah Expressway is going through my Constituency. Since there are blocks of flats there, has any attempt been made to find out the views of the residents, before it was decided to put a highway between those blocks?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not consider that is necessary. If any resident of an HDB estate finds that he is adversely affected, he can apply to the HDB to move to a new flat.

Column: 665

HDB FLATS
(Situation)


    8. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many Housing and Development Board flats are currently available for sale; (b) how many flats will be completed by the end of 1986; (c) what is the number of applications for flats as at the latest convenient date; and (d) whether the HDB has plans to review its building programmes if there is a possibility of an oversupply of HDB flats.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of HDB flats available for sale as at 28th February 1986, was 18,465. A total of 40,000 flats is scheduled for completion in 1986. As at 28th February 1986, the number of applications for purchase of HDB flats was 52,219.

    The HDB's building programme is always reviewed every six months to take into account changes in demand. The programme will be adjusted if there is a possibility of an oversupply of HDB flats.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether it is true that some HDB flats were not taken up by purchasers for more than a year. If so, why were such flats not taken up?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, because HDB has built a very large number of flats, in fact, slightly ahead of the demand, the purchaser has become very choosy. He continuously rejects the flat. Some of them, even though they have accepted the flat initially, declined later. This has resulted in the flat being vacant for a long time.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Will the Minister consider, assuming that these flats are in so-called less popular estates, easing the down payment and other payment terms, to make these so-called less popular areas more attractive?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the down payment for a small flat for the lower income group has been reduced to a very attractive term. It is only 5%.

Column: 666



     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sorry, the Minister has misunderstood my question. Generally, the down payment is 20% for everybody, even for the less popular estates.

     Mr Speaker: Let us have your supplementary question, please.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: For the less popular estates, will the Minister consider reducing the general down payment so that more people can take up those flats?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will not change the rules. I think the present rules are still satisfactory.

Column: 666

SECURITY MEASURES AT CHANGI AIRPORT


    9. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Communications and Information whether he will inform the House of the security measures that are enforced at the Changi Airport and whether these are adequate; whether other measures are being contemplated and whether passengers will be inconvenienced.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, security measures at Changi Airport are in line with those adopted by other major international airports. This is acknowledged by airlines using Changi Airport. The security experts of the International Air Transport Association (IATA) have also expressed the view that our airport security system is satisfactory and of a high standard.

    Together with the police, our airport authorities regularly review the airport security system. They are in touch with IATA and ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organization) on the latest developments in airport security and enforcement. Improved measures and equipment adopted by other major airports are introduced from time to time. Regular exercises are also held to test the system and the alertness of security personnel as well as to ensure that our security system functions smoothly at all times. Our security system is also obviously severely dependent on the quality of personnel that we recruit.

Column: 667



    Members may have read in the newspapers recently a report about a boy who entered the restricted area without a boarding pass. Investigations suggest that certain security officers may have had a lapse of vigilance. The boy managed to slip past the checkpoint at the entrance of the departure lounge. However, he was soon spotted by a security supervisor. The boy attempted to escape and went through a holding room. He was finally stopped by a security officer and a cabin crew and handed over to the security supervisor.

    Sir, in the light of this recent incident, security procedures have been reviewed. Police officers, airport security personnel as well as airline personnel have been asked to exercise greater vigilance.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the light of the Minister's reply, can he assure this House that the security officers will be more efficient in the discharge of their duties in the light of the recent incident?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, security personnel have been instructed to be more vigilant in the light of the recent incident.

Column: 667

WORLD TRADE CENTRE OPEN CARPARKS
(Reduction in charges)


    10. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for Communications and Information whether he will consider reducing the charges at the World Trade Centre open carparks from $1.20 to $0.60 per hour as the carparks are outside the Central Business District and there is normally no excessive demand.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am pleased to inform the hon. Member for Telok Blangah that the Port of Singapore Authority has at its meeting last month decided to reduce the parking charges for the open car parks at Maritime Square, as there are now sufficient parking lots to meet the heavy demand during popular exhibitions.

    The parking charges at these open car parks will be reduced from $1.20 per hour to $0.60 per hour with effect from 1st April, 1986.

Column: 668



     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Will the Minister confirm that these rates will also apply to the car park across the road at the bus interchange where a hawker centre is located?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the reduction in parking charges will be applied to the car parks in that vicinity.

Column: 668

REDUCTION OF ROAD TAX AND EXTENSION OF PARF
TO COMPANY CARS


    11. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Communications and Information, in view of the current economic recession, whether his Ministry will consider (i) reducing road tax, and (ii) extending Preferential Additional Registration Fee entitlement to Q-plate cars.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have answered the first part of the Member's question in reply to a question asked by the Member for Fengshan yesterday as well as subsequent supplementary questions asked by other Members. I shall proceed to the second part of the question.

    Sir, as for PARF for company cars, there is no need to offer it at the moment since company cars already enjoy tax concessions on the depreciation of their cars. There is no need, therefore, to offer additional incentives for these cars.

Column: 668

NATIONAL RESERVES
(Particulars)


    12. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance (a) what is the amount of Singapore's national reserves as at 31st December 1985; (b) what types of investments are the reserves put in; and (c) what were the returns from these investments for the past five years.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore's official foreign reserves on 31st December 1985, was S$27,080.1 million.

    The reserves are invested in a diversified mix of asset classes, countries and currencies. The main assets would include gold, cash, Treasury bills and Government bonds. The distribution changes from time

Column: 669

to time, depending on the expected yields of the various investment instruments.

    It is not Government's policy to disclose the returns earned on the investments of our national reserves. Most countries have the same policy of not disclosing the returns on their reserves.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister explain what is the reason for not disclosing the returns?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: It is not customary practice.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Are there any reasons for it?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: I understand the implication of what the Member for Anson says. This is his common practice. If he has any implication, I suggest he says it out loud.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: What are the reasons?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: There are no reasons that I need give you. If there are any aspersions you want to cast, I would like to hear them before I answer you.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I think that if the reserves belong to the people -

     Mr Speaker: Your supplementary question, Mr Jeyaretnam.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: - should they not be told what the returns are? This is my supplementary question.

     Mr Speaker: Yes, carry on.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Should not the people be told what they are getting on their reserves? Does the Minister realize that it is a weak answer to say "it is the practice". The practice may be all wrong. And if it is wrong, does he not realize it should be discontinued?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have absolutely nothing to hide. I can assure the Member for Anson that, in fact the returns on our assets are more than adequate and up to international standards. I am merely refusing to say anything because I want him to come out and say exactly what he means.

Column: 670



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Why do you not disclose them?

     Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio): May I know from the Minister whether we have invested some of our reserves in the Japanese Yen?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: A significant proportion, Sir.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: What percentage of these investments is abroad and what is the percentage locally?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: By the nature of the reserves which are held by the Board of Currency Commissioners and by the MAS, they are entirely abroad.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Would the Minister inform this House whether there are investments in stocks and in properties as well?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: The properties and stocks are held by the GSIC, which exclude the reserves we are talking about here.

Column: 670

SKILLS DEVELOPMENT
(Particulars)


    13. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance (a) how many local companies have applied for and been granted funds from the Skills Development Fund; (b) what is the total number of employees who have benefitted from the Fund; (c) whether there are any training programmes being designed to benefit general workers; and (d) whether any plans are being worked out with the Vocational and Industrial Training Board to provide courses suitable for workers to upgrade their educational and technical skills to help them increase productivity.

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, the SDF operates three main grant schemes for promoting training, mechanization and development consultancy. Todate more than 7,400 companies have responded.

    Under the Training Grant Scheme, 3,975 or 61% out of the total of 6,538 successful companies are local.

    As for the Interest Grant for Mechanization Scheme, 717 or 65% out of the total of 1,103 successful applications are from local companies.

Column: 671



    The Development Consultancy Scheme is restricted to local companies. It has supported 135 companies with grants for the engagement of external consultants to upgrade their business operations.

    Under the Training Grant Scheme, the SDF had made grant commitments to support the training of a total of 311,806 trainees.

    SDF has been actively looking for training opportunities for general workers. Its latest project is the Core Skills for Effectivenss and Change (COSEC) programme which will give workers permanent ownership of a set of five core skills that will prepare them for occupational competence and the capacity to adapt to change. COSEC is likely to have an impact on some 300,000 services, sales and clerical workers who would typically earn less than $800 per month.

    SDF has been working closely with the VITB in funding all of VITB's continuing education and training programmes. VITB's apprenticeship schemes, joint industrial/VITB courses and the Modular Skills Training scheme have all be granted approval-in-principle support by the SDF. These courses help workers upgrade their educational and technical skills.

Column: 671

MEDICAL SERVICES IN NORTHERN AND EASTERN
PARTS OF SINGAPORE
(Provision)


    14. Encik Ibrahim Othman asked the Minister for Health whether there are any plans to provide medical services for people living in the northern and eastern parts of Singapore; and, if so, when are they expected to be implemented.

     The Minister of State for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, I will answer on behalf of my Minister.

    Hospital services for the people living in the northern and eastern parts of Singapore are currently provided by Changi Hospital, Toa Payoh Hospital and Tan Tock Seng Hospital. In addition, primary health services are provided by six polyclinics, five maternal and child health clinics and six outpatient dispensaries.

Column: 672



    The Ministry plans to build a 200-bedded community hospital at Ang Mo Kio. This is expected to be completed by the end of 1988. In addition, the Ministry plans to renovate Toa Payoh and Tan Tock Seng Hospitals and at the same time upgrade a number of the C class beds into B2 class beds for which there is a demand.

    The Ministry has set aside sites for the building of new hospitals in Bedok, Woodlands and Hougang. As to when these hospitals will be built will depend upon the demand and the occupancy of beds within the existing hospitals.

    The Ministry plans to build one new polyclinic in each of the larger HDB new towns in the northern and eastern sectors, and these are: 

        1988:    Hougang, Tampines.

        1989:    Yishun, MacPherson.

        1990:    Woodlands


    Each of these polyclinics will provide general outpatient, maternal and child health and school health services as well as rehabilitation and day-care for the elderly.

     Encik Ibrahim Othman: Sir, can the Minister inform the House what plans does the Ministry of Health have for the reserved hospital site in Tanah Merah constituency in Bedok?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have just stated, the site has been reserved and the timing for the building of the hospital there will depend upon the demand and the occupancy of the existing hospitals.

     Mr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Sir, what type of health care will be given through the community hospital?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: The community hospitals will not be acute hospitals. Patients who require longer term care, for example, those who are recovering from orthopaedic surgery and who require a lower activity type of care will then be referred there and hospitalized there.

Column: 673

FOREIGN WORKERS' LEVY
(Request for reduction)


    15. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Acting Minister for Labour if the government will further assist industries to reduce operational cost by reducing the Foreign Workers' Levy, since the government has already decided to reduce the employers' Central Provident Fund contributions by 15% points.
